text: - My name's Mike Lyons.
I'm the CISO at a company called Cribl.
I'm in the security industry.

So generative AI is both a
positive and a negative for us.
I think on the positive sides,

it's allowing us to enable
some of our more early

to career staff to be able
to execute against things

and help them figure out some
more technical challenges.
On the negative side, it's the data,

we have to think about what
data we're going to include

in our Gen AI story, and
be very thoughtful about
where it is and how we leverage it
to ensure that we get accurate results.

I think the general
public believes that AI
is a thing or a person,

and that they're going
to get hacked by it,
so they are generally afraid of it.

I believe that there are use
cases that can help be defined
for the general public,

so they can understand
how to adopt it easier,

or at least have a
little less fear attached
to using Gen AI.
So balancing security model safety
and fast delivery with generative AI
starts with the data in my opinion.
If you understand the data
and you know the data that you have

that you're going to be
applying your models against,
you'll be at a much faster pace

and the ability to execute is
gonna be considerably higher
because the results

are gonna be understood
a little bit better.
When it comes to model safety,
we're gonna look to leverage technologies

to help reduce exploitation
of those models.
AWS can support us on our Gen AI journey

by better enabling interactions
with our different data,

being able to explain to us
other use cases that they feel

that they can help us
work faster, build faster,
and deliver faster for our customers.

AWS helps my software
company be more acceptable
within the the market that we operate.

We're a B2B SaaS company
selling into large enterprises.

AWS is a strong brand and
a strong trusted partner
for them and for us.
(upbeat music)
